name: Breiðavík - Golden Sand Beach in Remote Westfjords
description: Breiðavík represents rare golden-sand beach in Iceland where volcanic country's typical black basalt beaches yield to unusual warm-colored sand creating tropical-appearing bay that contradicts Nordic stereotypes when bright weather illuminates golden-yellow sands against azure waters, dramatic mountain backdrops, and grass-covered slopes producing scene more reminiscent of Mediterranean coast than North Atlantic island—this chromatic anomaly results from non-volcanic sediment sources including shell fragments and glacial flour creating lighter coloration than basaltic black sand dominating most Icelandic coastline. The wide sweeping bay near towering Látrabjarg bird cliffs (approximately 12 kilometers distance) positions Breiðavík as component of broader Westfjords touring corridor where visitors combine golden beach experience with puffin viewing, seal spotting, and dramatic coastal scenery in single multi-day excursion to Iceland's most remote and least-visited region where infrastructure remains minimal and tourism development lags behind accessible southern and western regions. The remote setting surrounded by dramatic mountains and grassy fields creates peaceful atmosphere where beach silence broken only by seabirds.
